summary.text_en: Crick and Watson discovered DNA double helix structure! He used physics thinking to unlock life's code. Later proposed 'Central Dogma': DNAâ†’RNAâ†’Protein, revealing genetic information flow direction.

story.text_en: On February 28, 1953, 37-year-old physicist Crick and young Watson completed DNA model at Cambridge Cavendish Lab. At noon, Crick rushed into Eagle Pub shouting: 'We have found the secret of life!' They drank much beer celebrating. Crick's physics background helped him understand X-ray diffraction data.

fun_facts.text_en: Crick originally studied physics, researched mines during WWII, switched to biology at 35!
The Eagle Pub where he announced discovery now has blue plaque commemorating that historic moment.
In later years he turned to neuroscience of consciousness, trying to scientifically explain consciousness mystery.

experiment.description_en: Crick and colleagues experimented with synthetic RNA sequences. They found: three bases encode one amino acid. For example, UUU encodes phenylalanine, GGG encodes glycine. Through systematic experiments, deciphered all 64 codons' corresponding amino acids.
experiment.why_en: Triplet code just enough to encode 20 amino acids (4Â³=64>20), while doublet insufficient (4Â²=16<20).

simple_explanation.text_en: DNA is like a recipe book, RNA is the copied version, protein is the cooked dish. Every three letters (bases) on DNA represent one ingredient (amino acid). Cells follow this recipe, step by step making various protein 'dishes', maintaining life activities.

impact.text_en: Crick not only discovered DNA structure, but proposed Central Dogma and deciphered genetic code, laying molecular biology's theoretical foundation. His work enabled humans to read and edit life's language, opening genetic engineering and synthetic biology era.
